repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Economic and Public Sector Reform
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic and Public Sector Reform
            Credit Project for Kenya had the following ratings: the
            outcome was unsatisfactory, the sustainability was likely,
            the institutional development impact was modest, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the borrower performance
            was unsatisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that
            conditions such as retrenching civil servants, or
            implementing an action plan are intermediate indicators,
            should be clearly specified in the program matrix.
            Far-reaching reforms, especially those requiring approval of
            parliament, require time to build support among key
            stakeholders. Assessing government commitment to reform is
            difficult, particularly when key decision-makers, such as
            the minister of finance, profess their commitment to the
            program. Understand the impact of the reforms on various
            stakeholders and work with government to develop mitigation
            strategies to gain support for reform. Focus on a limited
            set of key reforms. Offer a series of annual single tranche
            budget support credits, rather than multitranche operations.
            Take care to build effective partnerships with the IMF and
            other donors in designing and supervising policy based
            lending operations. Consult with the parliament, civil
            society, and other stakeholders in designing and
            implementing the reform program, and develop an effective
            communications strategy. Support increased participation of
            the private sector in the economy through deregulation,
            concessioning, and other forms of public-private
            partnerships, rather than insisting on privatization of
            specific enterprises.

repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Economic and Public Sector Reform
            Credit Project : release of second tranche and waiver of two
            conditions and amendment of Development Credit Agreement

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic and Public Sector Reform
            Credit Project was prepared to assist the government
            jumpstart the implementation of Kenya's Interim Poverty
            Reduction Strategy Paper (I-PRSP), and, to improve the
            outlook for economic growth, and poverty reduction in the
            medium term, initially by containing the fragile
            macroeconomic situation, and fiscal difficulties. Although
            macroeconomic stability masks significant structural
            weaknesses in the economy, and, from a policy viewpoint, the
            structure of public spending seemingly favors a recurrent
            wage-bill expenditure, leaving little for investment in
            physical, human capital, and services delivery, commitments
            nonetheless, to improving the economic governance framework
            are strong, much beyond the conditionality of the Credit.
            Ten conditions regarding institutional auditing reforms,
            financial regulations to improve the budget process, the
            transparency of public spending, donor finance payments, the
            procurement process, the legal framework on privatization of
            public utilities, and, some legal and judicial reforms have
            been met. However, two conditions, civil service
            restructuring, and financing of core poverty programs, have
            not been fully met, but for which a waiver is recommended
            based on the fact that substantial retrenchment was
            achieved, and that, while core poverty expenditures have
            been technically difficult (in a way not fully appreciated
            at the time of project design), steps have been taken to
            strengthen mechanisms to fully protect spending on these programs.

repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Economic and Public Sector Reform
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic and Public Sector Reform
            Credit Project aims to support the implementation of the
            Government's interim poverty reduction strategy paper
            (IPRSP). The IPRSP aims to improve the living conditions for
            Kenyans through measures to promote broad-based growth and
            poverty reduction by encouraging income-generating
            activities and improved access to basic social services. The
            credit will focus on a) improvement in the governance
            framework, particularly in areas that will improve
            transparency and prudential over-sight of government
            spending, and b) introduction of a budget consistent with
            the resource envelope constraints determined by a realistic
            medium-term expenditure framework (MTEF). c) Related to the
            MTEF, a shift is envisaged in the composition of public
            expenditure towards the priority poverty reduction programs
            identified in the forthcoming full PRSP. Other core areas
            include: d) implementation of right-sizing of the civil
            service, in line with the core functions of the government
            and the priorities of the PRSP, and e) implementation of a
            new and more ambitious privatization strategy. The credit
            will improve the environment for economic governance and
            strengthen market confidence so that both public and private
            resources will be used efficiently to promote growth and
            improve living conditions.
